captions.text:
Mixing water with electricity is typically
discouraged, and for good reason, but in this

project we're pumping electricity into water,
and a bit of drain cleaner to create a poor

mans power controller. You might have heard
of a Variac. This is the Scariac.

In a couple of other projects, we fashioned
a homemade stick welder using parts we salvaged

from old appliances. I powered the device
with 240 VAC, and that was plenty of power,

but we still needed a way to adjust the current.
I built this device to control alternating

current, so we have the ability to play with
adjustable power settings, on a budget.

Now this concept is about as dangerous as sticking
two live wires in a bucket of water,

it can be deadly, so it's important to know,
and understand the risks. To build this Scariac

we'll need a 4 gallon container to hold our
electrolyte, and I like this one because it's

got a lid that snaps on tight. I cut a piece
of board so that it measures at 16"x14" because

that fits on top, leaving a 3" overhang on
the side. I made this plastic template for

marking holes for where the switch and outlet
will go, and a few other markings based on

these measurements. To cut the holes out,
let's drill the corners first, then use a

jigsaw to cut the sides. We can use the light
switch as a template for marking where the

two holes will need to be drilled. This part
is optional, but let's go ahead and finish

the edges with a 1/2" rounding bit on the
router table. By profiling the tops and bottoms

of all the edges, we're left with a nice smooth
finish. Next, we'll need 2 pieces of 2"x2",

and I had these ones left over, from when
we made, our mousetrap hand guns, which you

can see in a different project. I drilled
a hole through the sides of the blocks 1/2"

from the top, and cut them down to 1-1/4"
so they looked like this. These blocks will

need to be secured flush with the top of the
center hole, so let's trace the edges and

drill 4 pilot holes on diagonals. They'll
eventually be held in place with screws from

the bottom side. I gave these parts a paint
job, and now the panel board is complete,

and we can move on to constructing the power
lever. All the parts for the power lever are

laid out here, and you can see they're mainly
1/2" PVC parts, as well as these other miscellaneous

bits of hardware. Now we can get to work priming
and cementing the PVC together so that we

end up with 2 sections that look like this.
They'll be fit together later on, but here
you can get a basic idea of how it's gonna work. We'll need to mark, and drill a hole

right through the lower part of the "T", then
make the hole bigger on the inner sides. The

hole has to be just big enough to allow the
head of a 2-1/2" bolt to pass through. Here

you can see I added a metal washer, and a
beveled rubber washer on the inside. At this

point, the 2 parts of the handle can be cemented
together, and the excess glue wiped away.

I decided to paint the handle red to give
it a nice contrast against the black.
We can add a rubber washer

to the bolt first, and the block gets pushed
on next, until you see about 1/4" of the bolt

poking out on the end. I added a washer and
a wing-nut to hold it in place, and now we

have the ability to adjust the tension of
the power lever. Now that our blocks are attached,

let's push the bottom part of the handle through
the hole, and secure the blocks to the board

using the screws we lined up earlier. At this
point, we're ready to wire up the electrical,

and this is how it's going to look when it's
finished. I started with two 17" pieces of

1/2" copper tubing. Let's make 4 markings
at 3, 4-1/2, 12-1/2, and 14". That should

leave us with an 8" gap between the middle
markings. Now we can use a hammer or bench

vise to compress the copper, allowing us to
bend it over easily. When all the markings

have been compressed, including the tips,
the electrode can be formed into a rectangle,

and should look like this. I've drilled a
hole through the center of the tips, continuing

into the tube itself, but only through one
side of it. For this electrode, let's add

a 4" plastic PVC riser, so that it lines up
flush with one of the edges. Then we can put

a screw right through it, so it's held between
the two pieces of copper. The other end of

this riser can screw into the bottom of our
power lever, making sure the copper bar is

facing forward. The other 4" riser gets added
into the power lever, and can be secured to

the copper as well. To form the 2nd electrode
holder, I added a PVC cap to a 6" PVC riser,

and used a belt sander, to grind away at the
top until it was completely flat. With the

power lever in the full upright position,
we can get a feel for where the longer risers

will need to be attached. Using 2 screws for
each riser, we can bite down into the riser

caps, securing them in position. Now the second
electrode can be added, adjusting it so it's

the same height as the first , and of course
2 more screws will fix the copper in place.

Now it's time to rig up the wiring for this
contraption. I've got some 12 gauge cable,

and a 2 prong plug. The plug opens up allowing
us to connect our 2 wires, and screws back

together, completing this end of the cable.
The black wire from the cable runs to the

light switch first, and connects to the screw
on the far side. The wire is cut, and connected

to the other screw on the switch, then continues
to this hole drilled through the board. On

the top side, you can see the wire is bent
over in an arch, and goes back through the

board, where it continues to the electrode
on the power lever. The electrode wire can
simply be connected by looping it behind the existing screw and fastening tight.

Let's use another piece of the black wire and connect
it to the other electrode in the same way.

You can see this wire connects to the outlet,
and gets held on with one of the gold screws.

This silver screw is connected to the white
wire running from the cable, and this completes

our electrical work. At this point we can
fasten the light switch and the outlet onto

the control board, and add the faceplates
for a finishing touch. This control panel

is fully functional, but if you wanted to
add a little more safety, you

could add a replaceable fuse, or even wire
up a circuit breaker. To finish up the system

we'll just need to modify this lid. We can
use a rotary tool with a cutting wheel to

cut along the inner edges leaving just the
rim intact. The inside hole has to be large

enough to allow both electrodes to fit in
freely, and when it's centered on the top,

we can screw together the 4 corners, so it's
all attached. This way, it clamps into position

perfectly every time. I wanted to add a piece
of trim around the power lever, so I stopped

at the grocery store and picked up a container
of bean dip. The empty container is exactly

the right size, and with just a little cutting,
and two pieces of double sided sticky tape,

it mounts right behind the power lever. Our
last step is to mix the electrolyte. I'm using

about 2 gallons of tap water, and that fills
the container up half way. To make the water

more conductive, we'll be using this crystal
drain cleaner because it's 100% lye.
This  stuff is so dangerous and so potent, that we'll only need 1/4 teaspoon mixed into the entire solution.

Now we can secure the control board in place,
connect the plug to a power source, and test

it out. Let's make sure the power lever is
pushed fully forward, before the switch is

turned on. Now the system is powered, and
you can see that if we gently pull the lever

back, the light begins to glow dimly. And
if we pull it all the way back, it increases

to full intensity. The switch is a kill switch
and will cut all the power to the system in

an instant. The main purpose of this contraption,
is to regulate current to our electrical devices.

Adding just a little power to an angle grinder
will cause the device to spin very slowly.

But pulling back on the lever will increase
the power until it reaches full speed.

The control panel has this loop of black wire,
that allows us to monitor the amperage, in

high power applications, like the arc welding
project. You can see that if we pull back

on the lever, the current climbs higher. An
interesting observation is that the voltage

is pretty much constant through the entire
cycle. The system can handle extremely high

electrical loads, and in contrast, it can
also make a table saw turn at a snails pace.

Pushing forward on the lever increases the
electrolytic resistance, and as a result,

the equipment slows down, or comes to a full
stop. Well now you know, how to control electricity

with water and a bit of drain cleaner. Remember,
that this has the power to kill you, and that's

why it's called the Scariac. If you liked
this project, perhaps you'll like some of
my others. Check them out at www.thekingofrandom.com

title: The Scariac (Poor Mans Variable Power Controller)
